IntroductionDear reader,I want to let you know WRC 6 is everything WRC 5 had to be. It has improved on all levels. It's the best game since 2010, when MIlestone was the developer. Kylotonn did a very good job out here. I can say it's worth your money. But please read further for it's shortcomings, what can be improved and what did it do good. I took my WRC 5 format, because it's good for the eye and it's not to long to read.What are the bad things about WRC 6:- Cockpit is bland- Cockpit has no fov and seat-adjustment, which is mandatory in every racing simulation game now. (It actually has, but it's still too far away for a triple/wide screen user. )- Cockpit is too far and too high seated for triple screens.(Even at Very Close)- Co-drivers sound a bit robotic; will explain further down below- Cannot use my analog handbrake- Wish there was a clutch, because I want to rev my hairpins, etc* (Link below)- Can cheat the start line by a few meters. - No false starts. There actually is but you can move. Read line above.- Eyefinity / triple screens fish eye-effect- AI is not affected by weather; like fog etc. - Sound at staggered start from other car can be annoying loud. - Online Challenges can be restarted. - Online hit or miss; people or no people online.- No shakedowns/recce.- Losing lightpod doesn't have consequenses. - The non-time based online challenge can be exploited- Expert mode is bugged/cheats and very unfair. Recommended to play at Hard, but can be too easy for some of us.- Extensive mud on the windshield is annoying. What do I like about WRC 6?- Taking damage? It means something here. I lost my handbrake, my brakes, my gears. Oh ♥♥♥♥.- Presentation is really nice. - Repair system is alright. Similar to Dirt Rally. - Online challenges etc. just like Dirt Rally. (and with a twist)- No restarts in Expert difficulty- Career is well done working up from J-WRC to WRC 1- Triple screen- FFB is very well done. It's has some effects DR nor RBR has.- Sound has improved a lot. - Visuals are outstanding. There is some real eyecandy- Narrow and longer roads finally!- Here and there good stuff too- Able to disable vignette, depth of field, etc. - 1:1 Stages. I watched the Finnish stage live a few months ago, and it's 1:1 the very same in-game. Impressive. - Expert difficulty is really challenging.- AI does not always lose or win by .100 secs, like WRC 5 had. - Tyre wear - Setup and tyres do affect your time and handling.- FFB and handling differs per surface, etc. - Cars can caught fire or anything else and the stage will be canceled then. :O - On top of that, stages are more narrow with more hazards; lots of areas to unsettled the car, mostly by way of ditches, cambers and pot-holes. There are actual reasons not to cut. What can Kylotonn improve in WRC 6 or for WRC 7?- Improve SAT. Counter-steering. - Physics can always be improved. It feels good in WRC 6, however. - Less grip, more momentum, etc. - Rally school- Wished the cockpit had fov and seat-adjustment for us triple screen or widescreen users- Prettier cockpits- Adapt a real fov and seat-adjustment like every other racing game has. Mandatory! - Perhaps it is an idea to put a real co-driver(s) in a D-box and let them record the pace-notes for some real good co-driver sound. Just like Paul Coleman did for DR. - Longer stages (20+ km and more)- Real stages, of course- Filter leader boards or separate, so not all kind of people are in the same leader board. I use Simulation for example, another person may use Amateur thus gain a advantage on me + restarts. - Triple screens could use an adjustment-thingy just like Assetto Corsa has, or Multi view like AMS etc has. - Able to see throttle, brake and wheel pressure when fiddling with the settings.- Able to choose linearity and saturation for pedals and wheel. - Analog handbrake- Maybe give the career some RPG-elements- Driving older licensed WRC cars- Historic mode, maybe. - API support, so our simdashes can actually be useful in this game. - Removable wheel and arms.- AI bit inconsistent here and there; Portugal and Australia were very easy, but the rest was not. (J-WRC season, expert) So AI needs to be rebalanced.* (Link below)- Non-restartable Online Challenges. - Performance optimizations. - Reverse and mirrored stages.- Sound can be better. - Could use leagues, like DR has, to prevent empty multiplayer. - Some more to improve but not very important- Repairsystem can be better. I want to repair parts of the car. Not "precentages" (Windshield broken? I want to repair the windshield, not the whole bodywork.)- I would actually prefer more bumps and uneven surfaces in the road. It still feels a bit flat in some countries. Italy was spot on. - Lock the steeringwheel rotation to their real life counterparts, and add wheel ratio- Expert mode must have a rebalance. Hard is too easy, Expert too hard. ConclusionI recommend this game. Kylotonn has really improved this game. It's the one of the best Rally games out now. It's better than WRC 5, even better than Loeb. It is however still a step below Dirt Rally and RBR, but WRC 6 is a worthy rally game. It only needs to expand and improve slowly.I am really glad Kylotonn listed to the community. I give the company a big thumb up for that too. Now keep it like that. I also hope the company will do WRC 7, WRC 8 etc, because it has with WRC 6 a good basis to work from. However, If FIA WRC decided to not going further with Kylotonn / BigBen.. I sincerely hope the engine, date, etc will transfer over to the current company so Kylotonn / BigBen can turn this game into a non-WRC licenced game, but towards hardcore and simulation thus being a direct competitor towards Codemasters's DR and hopefully DR 2. Why? Because DR and Dark Souls are why. People don't want to be spoonfed anymore.Tested with a Thrustmaster TX, G27 GTeyed pedals, Heusinkveld Seq Shifter.Regarding improvements for a Rally game in general taken from my DR manifesto:http://steamcommunity.com/app/310560/discussions/0/357287304436205237/Regarding the clutch in WRC 6http://steamcommunity.com/app/458770/discussions/0/343788552537157965/?tscn=1475872960Regarding inconsistent AIhttp://steamcommunity.com/app/458770/discussions/1/343788552543192990/

												After more than 300 hours played of Dirt Rally and SLRE, I just needed an hour to conclude that this game can't be recommended for any rally enthusiast in its actual state. The major technical problem is a horrible frame stutter that, according to the forums, comes from WRC 5 and still wasn't fixed by developers. This stuttering really breaks immersion, and it happens even with a rig capable of delivering a frame rate that more than doubles today's standard refresh rate (60fps). So, definitely it's not a matter of performance in this case. Any proposed workaround haven't fixed this problem for me.Also, the force feedback feels very off, especially if compared to other racing titles. It's just bad, there's no other way to say this. I tried every racing title on the last couple years. DR, SLRE, Assetto Corsa, RRRE, Project Cars, you name it. WRC's FFB is by far the worst. Adding to the uninspiring visuals, this makes the (many) tracks available look and feel the same. All of them are really flat and boring, with a serious lack of surfacing work. Sound effects are okay.Unfortunately, this game can't be compared with Dirt Rally at any level, and even Sebastien Loeb's EVO, with all its limitations, offers a much better sim experience. Maybe, like me - and many other people, you just want another rally game to have some "detox" from the so few DR's stages, and waited to get WRC 6 with a better pricing. But even in this scenario, I don't think it's worth it. I know Kylotonn improved a lot if comparing to WRC 5, but they still need to fix a lot of things, with this game-breaking frame stutter as priority. I'm really confident that they'll manage to fix some of these problems to make WRC 7 a worthwhile evolution. Let's just wait.

												For years now, the WRC branded games have been nothing but disappointment. The last one I played properly was WRC 3, and that game was just hateful. Rubbish physics, nasty graphics and a soundtrack that could give a deaf person a migraine. Years later, I expected something better, especially given the rights have changed company. I also read a few other reviews before buying and it sounded somewhat promising. I didn’t go into this game expecting a full simulator like Dirt Rally, but I did expect better. Firstly, the stages are rather poor, as they really don’t represent the rally they are for well at all. There is still an over-reliance on hairpins to make the stages seem longer. I also expected better real stages. The game boasts that they have represented real WRC stages in the game. Don’t be fooled by that, they have only rendered the short spectator stages. The physics have come a long way from WRC 3. There is a decent feel to the cars in the flowing sections of the stages, but they are far too loose in the sharp turns, defaulting to a drift very quickly (even the front wheel drive DS3s). It just ruins the feel with the car and prevents you having any confidence in the car.The pacenotes are pathetic. Games from 10 years ago did a better job than this. They are very robotic. You can tell the developers recorded the bare minimum and stitched them together. This means they are very jerky and lack any flow at all. They are also wrong in places and the timing is appalling, even after changing the delivery time. Once again, it just prevents you from having any confidence in the notes.There are good features. The graphics aren’t too bad (but Dirt Rally has it beaten) and the career mode is decent, but the game just doesn’t feel finished. The AI is too easy, and there are just some moments that make you feel like the game just isn’t a polished product. For example, in a head to head super special stage, I crossed the line behind the AI car in the other lane. It then said I won the stage by 20 seconds. Amazing.Finally, the little “facts” on the loading screens are just stupid. They didn’t need to be! It only requires a bit of reading into the sport to get those right, but most of them are just pointless or wrong. For example, the fact I got before Portugal was saying the rally is run solely on gravel (which is true), but the Portuguese stage I did had a tarmac section in it! It almost feels like the game developers have absolutely no idea about the sport they are representing at all. When will the WRC realise that Codemasters do a far better job at games like this and give them the rights to the championship!?

												WRC 6 reminds me a lot of the old WRC games under EvoStudios back on the PS1 & 2, otherwise known as the glory days of WRC gaming. Let's just get one thing out the way first though... one cannot logically compare this game to DiRT Rally; I love DR, but WRC 6 is a licensed game, therefore must appeal to a wider audience. DR is a passion project, and Codies had more creative freedom with restrictions largely limited to vehicle licensing. Expect a ceiling. Anyway, it's clear to see that WRC 5 was largely just a stepping stone on to better things. They didn't have long to make that game either, and the result was evident. However, WRC 6 has improved in all areas, from visuals and sound, all the way down to quality of content. Stages are narrower with unforgiving elements (mostly between 6-8km long, with some a little shorter or a little longer), pacenotes are less robotic (yet still c&p) and more accurate, car models are better, and most importantly the cars themselves feel like they have more weight and contact with the road surface, and generally the feel and appearance of car physics are much more polished.Damage model has been developed to be more realistic, which means it's more progressive and dynamic depending on where you hit the car. You can also suffer from punctures during the stage, in which case you will need to stop and change the wheel. Cockpit cam is a little more zoomed out, and you can now freely look around the car, and take a peek at the drivers body if you wish. Still on cameras, the chase cam has also been improved, if that's your thing. It's very much like the early 2000's WRC games; more fluid following, compared to how stiff and horrid is has been in recent years. Performance wise, it runs perfectly. I'm getting 60fps solid with most of the settings on the highest quality. Alongside performance WRC 6 is also a nice looking game, and far better than the titles in recent years. It looks a lot more natural by way of colouring and post fx, and car and stage textures are very good. This is the first time I've been this happy playing the first few hours of a WRC game in a long, long time. I'm just glad I can finally say that again.

TL:DRWRC6 is a huge improvement over the previous game in the series. They really paid attention to every last detail which makes rallying a joy and delivered a great fun and challenging rally game. If you're a complete casual or more of a hardcore fan, there should be something for everyone in here.9/10Full review...if you can call it oneSo I've been playing this quite a lot just in the couple days after launch, and I must say I am very impressed. It's interesting what a year of work can bring if you work on the right bits and pieces. People should note tho that this is not suppose to be Dirt Rally 2 or something, mainly because it's based at a much wider audience than DR is. But just because of that, it doesn't mean it's a bad game either. In fact, it's a blast! Things that should be noted are:PROS:- Very detailed and well made/updated tracks - There's 14 different rallies, including China, so there's plenty of environments to race through. A big variety of destinations (something DR actually lacks...) with great attention to detail.- Fun for everyone - Considering it's a licensed game, it has to be made so it can suit as many people as possible. And I must say, great job on achieving that, because with assists, even the most casual rally fans can have a go without major issues, while cracking it up to simulation mode, brings a challenge even to the more hardcore audience. Even after playing around 200 hours on DR at the time, I must admit I find this game more enjoyable, it's the perfect ballance of fun and challenge.- Graphics/sounds/physics - a bunch of well improved elements which make the game that more enjoyable.- Splitscreen - Not for everybody but I personally really appreciate this feature. Thank you! :DCONS:- Co-driver - Although he does get the job done, there are times he cannot manage to deliver the pacenotes in time. It often happens, at least in my case, that I overtake him and he can't keep up. So there's something that'll need a bit more work.- Replay cameras - The onboard cameras that are used most of the time aren't really anything special...would be nice to see trackside cameras through most of the stages.- Track variety - Now bare with me on this...I know I mentioned tracks under pros as well, but there's a few things that should be noted, if not else maybe for next years game I suppose. Track selection is great, BUT there are only a few per rally. About 3-4 plus a "Super Special Stage" if the rally even has one. Not to mention some tracks are more or less the same layout than in the previous game, maybe extended a kilometer or so. So quick suggestions to devs, do what codemasters do, make the tracks available in reverse as well. BOOM, instant double rally lenght. Maybe could be considered for next year.Overall, WRC 6 is a great "simcade" like racing game. If you're a rally fan and are looking for a game which delivers both fun and a good challenge, this game should be one to consider. I'm giving it a solid 9/10 considering they only had a year to develop it all as well. Good job Kylotonn, looking forward to future titles already!

												I was sceptical about trying WRC 6 at first, but after reading a few positive reviews from fellow DiRT Rally veterans, I decided to give it a go. And I'm so glad I did. I was hooked from the first stage.The physics and FFB are first class: realistic and intuitive. It's how a car should behave in both low and high speeds. You can feel the weight of the car through the steering wheel and know what to do to make the car behave. The second really impressive aspect of the game is the stages. There are only five per country, but all official countries being represented it's quite enough. And the different rallies are very well portrayed atmospherically and through the surfaces. It's clear that a lot of effort went into stage design, especially the super special stages which are modeled accurately after real life ones.The career mode is great. I was highly motivated to finish the whole thing. With hard difficulty it required absolute focus without much practice, so I'm guessing the expert difficulty requires both. Which is how it should be.I still haven't encountered a single bug. It seems to me a very well polished product.Other positive things to be mentioned: the damage model, online multiplayer mode (simultaneous racing with others showing up as coloured shadow cars), sounds, tire model and achievements.Things to work on: camera modes, more detailed car setups and maybe some proofreading of the pacenotes.Overall it's a fantastic rally game which captures the spirit of WRC well. I have high hopes for future games of the series, which I hope will feature even more real life stages and maybe a wider range of cars and classes. I'm won't go into comparisons between this and DiRT Rally as they are both great games, and deserve to be enjoyed individually.

												First review I've done, here goes nothing...Firstly, this game is a HUGE improvement on WRC5, although that wouldn't be entirely difficult. As soon as you jump into career mode, you can tell the developers have actually thought about the product they are producing. This is evident in little things such as seeing another driver start the stage before you (and its actually the car ahead of you in the timings, not a random). Another nice touch which I appreciated is the fact stages can be cancelled due to bad weather, an accident or too many spectators on the stage. The handling and FFB feels really rewarding to me. You can really feel when you are driving on snow and ice (steering goes light with lack of grip) and on tarmac (steering is harder as there is lots of grip). The stages are much more realistic as they are longer and narrower with a lot more obstacles to prevent cutting and a lot more spectators lining the stage which really immerses you into the world of rally. In addition, the stages are accurate to that of the real rally. For example, the constant corners in Corsica, the square corners and hairpins in Germany along with fast stretches on narrow roads. WRC 5 was guilty of having constant hairpins on every rally, as if the developers have never seen a rally stage. Thankfully, this isnt the case in WRC6!The damage model is more realistic now as well, although it could be more realistic for my liking. Punctures can occur along stages, forcing you into either struggling to the end or replacing the tire, costing a 30 second time penalty. Again, a nice touch by the developers. The best stages are the super specials which are SO MUCH FUN to drive. The downside of this game for me is how boring career mode can become. Seb Ogier wins almost every single rally, and the AI time appear to be fake as you could lose to your opponent on a super special but still be quickest?! The developers need to look at F1 2016 to spice up their career mode. I like the categories you have to go through on your path to WRC, but once you get there my god it is dreary. Career mode should evolve, like F1 2016's. For example, in 3 years time M-Sport are suddenly very quick and VW arent. Overall, the game looks stunning. Visibility is poor in foggy conditions which is a real challenge. Stages are nice and long and ready to kill you at any moment. Rally fans, it is a must buy. Casual gamers, you could enjoy it. I believe this game could get you interested in the world of rallying.8/10. Sort out the AI!

I think it will take quite long for me to memorize any stage.++ Good sensation of speed including increasing car instability at very high speeds+ Different road surfaces make a big difference in the amount of grip and the required braking distances. Loss of grip on icy sections or through ponds of water is quite credible.+ Good FFB right out of the box+ Good sound. Although I must admit that nowadays cars sound quite "meh".+ I like the way flat tyres are simulated.+ On sunny days the light effects are quite nice.+ Credible physics in simulation mode (in my layman opinion)o I don't like the German co-driver. Luckily the British one is quite ok.- Only today's WRC cars available. No classics :-(- Bad balance of AI strength between different rally events. On difficulty level "Difficult" in the WRC I managed to win a couple of rallies while at others I did not stand a chance without making any major mistakes and once was even worse than most of the WRC 2 drivers.- The road surface is almost entirely flat without any potholes or significant camber. Especially the latter point is way better in DiRT Rally.- Some rally events contain the same stage multiple times, and this so only in the same direction. Why no reverse direction?And last but not least the most annoying points, which make this game sometimes really unlikable for me:-- At the Super Special Stages, where you are racing directly against another opponent, this other car's engine is louder than your own car's engine. This is quite annoying if you are using manual gear shift and would like to shift according to your engine's rev sound.-- The image brightness in the game is generally way too dark. Since the game does not provide a gamma correction or brightness feature in the graphics settings, the only way tweak the brigthness is via the monitor's settings. Even on sunny summer stages at midday you sometimes can get the feeling of driving in the twilight. What makes things worse is that the car's headlights have a felt reach of only about 5 metres in front of your car. Foggy stages or stages at night time are like a blind flight and thus become a real pain to drive. Under such weather conditions I don't stand a chance against the AI's stage times.-- On some gravel stages the windscreen gets more and more dirty over time. This, in general, could have been a quite nice and immersive feature. But it is not: the screen gets dirty quite quickly even on straight sections under dry conditions. On twisty sections it's even worse so that I sometimes drive with my wipers active all the time, which is quite ridiculous under dry weather conditions and even more annoying in combination with the game's already quite bad overall brightness.-- The cockpit view offers 5 different camera positions with varying distances to the windscreen. For some cars (like the Polo) there is only one position where it's actually possible to see the gear indicator all the time. For other cars another position may have to be configured in order to see the gear indicator. At the same time the broad sun protection strip at the top of the windscreen makes the already dark road environment even darker. So there may be no perfect camera position where you can see at the same time the gear indicator and where the sun protection strip disturbs you the least.After having just finished a Rally Portugal event under mostly very frustrating visibility conditions, I am quite annoyed at the moment and give WRC 6 a rating of 6 out of 10.Update on 2017-01-07: After having permanently switched from cockpit to bonnet view some of the aforementioned negatives are no longer disturbing so that I change my rating to a 7 out of 10.

They are actually good (apart from the co-driver who still lacks human emotion-the pace-notes are good though) and shows they have taken the time improve aspects of the game. It even has local co-op which further reinforces it's position as an arcade game. There aren't tonnes of tracks but there are ones from each of the locations on the WRC calendar, which is nice. The cars aren't all copy and paste replicas of one another either and it actually feels like a step up going from WRC 2 to WRC class.  I'll re-iterate- this ISN'T a rally sim. Approach this game like it is one and you'll ♥♥♥♥ing hate it, but approach it as a game you can pick up and play for a few hours, and you'll see WRC 6 in an entirely different light. I'll finish up and say no, don't buy this at full price; by no means is this worth £34.99 not when DiRT 3 and other such titles are cheaper. If it's on sale though (steam or otherwise) grab it. 												As mentioned numerous times already, WRC 6 is a significant improvement over the previous titles in this series. Perhaps the biggest endorsement of this game I can offer, is to say that after playing 210 hours of Dirt Rally (the benchmark against which all rally titles will now be measured), I still immediately enjoyed WRC 6. Well, almost immediately - I had to experiment with the wheel settings for about 30 minutes before finding settings I was satisfied with.  It was definitely worth it, as the game quickly went from being mediocre, to very, very good. I'm using a Fanatec CSR Elite and the feedback and feel is excellent.Anyway, let's get on with inevitable Dirt Rally comparison. While the game isn't as visually spectacular as Dirt Rally, the graphics are a marked improvement on previous versions, and generally very pleasing to the eyes.  The game doesn't appear to be too demanding of your hardware either, and will run in 1080p at very high settings on my machine (which has a fairly modest spec sheet by today's standards). I have no complaints about the audio either. Again, probably not quite up to Dirt's standards, but more than adequate nonetheless. The physics? Well, that will really depend on your perspective, but for me, WRC 6 falls short of Dirt Rally in this regard, as the physics simply don't have that realistic simulation feel.  If however, you prefer less challenging, 'arcade' style physics, then you'll likely enjoy the car behaviour in WRC 6 more than Dirt Rally.  I turned the settings to simulation and turned off all assists, and I find the handling to be a good balance between arcade and simulation, and for the most part, challenging enough to be enjoyable.WRC 6 also can't compete with Dirt Rally for variety of content, the latter offering Hill Climb and Rally Cross events in addition to the standard Rally events. These additions are by no means a novelty either, they are brilliantly executed, and keep you coming back for more.  WRC 6 does however offer an esports competition, an officail online WRC if you like, which is a great addition for all of us wannabe WRC drivers.If it's starting to sound like a one-sided fight, and a clear victory for Dirt Rally, well it's not quite that simple. If, like me, you're a WRC fanatic, then WRC 6 trumps Dirt in one key area - official content. You get all 14 rounds of the 2016 championship, all the official drivers, teams, cars etc. which is very appealing for hardcore WRC fans. The stages are fanatstic too.  Rally enthusiasts will be pleased to know that the stages are now properly narrow, and some of those stages are now also seriously long, and will really test your concentration levels. Objectively, WRC 6 falls short of Dirt Rally in almost every way, but it's a game that seems to be greater than the sum of its parts, and for me, is at times even more enjoyable than Codies' recent masterpiece.  Time will tell if WRC 6 has the enduring appeal of Dirt Rally, but at the moment I'm loving it, and can't see myself getting bored of it anytime soon. If you're a rally fan and a keen gamer, do yourself a favour...

WORTH GETTING IF YOU ARE WILLING TO TWEAK THINGS AND PRACTISE UNTIL IT FEELS RIGHT AND USE SIMILAR SETTINGS TO MIMIC THE LIGHT FEEL OF THOSE SUGGESTED BY 'REAL RALLY DRIVER' for DIRT RALLY  Here is the video with the settinggs demonstrated for Dirt Rally:


YouTube™ Video: Logitech G25/G27 - DiRT Rally Force Feedback Settings by Real Rally Driver 

			Views: 36,111		

			I had a few requests from my previous video on what settings I used with DiRT Rally for my Logitech G25 steering wheel. So I decided to make a small video which shows the settings I use for the...		

Ok I'll keep this brief.  Bought this game having already played DIRT RALLY loads using G27.  I had to tweak that game a lot until I was happy and only when I stumbled upon the amazing Irish REAL RALLY DRIVER settings (can't remember the guy's name) - much LIGHTER settings, less is more, get that wheel light and movable rather than all heavy and stodgy.    Was initially immediately dissapointed with WRC 6, it felt terrible - FFB felt plastic WAY WAY TOO HEAVY and also relying WAY too much on the self-aligning torque of the wheel itself rather than any actual feel from the road/tyres etc.HOWEVER - after tweaking around with the wheel settings and logitech profiler. and the in game settings I got things feeling pretty close to what I was used to in DR and AFTER A FEW STAGES WAS HAVING ALMOST AS MUCH FUN AS DIRT RALLY, although there is clearly less detail in the feel and the graphics aren't as immersive.I am now happy with this game and don't regret the purchase, in fact it's nice to have a Rally Game which is slightly less involved than DR and also a little easier once you get used to it.  If you're happy with lighter FFB settings on your wheel for Rally Driving (and you should be, less is more in Rally Driving!), this game CAN be made to work.    Here are my settings for G27:Logitech Profiler (Excatly the same as 'REAL RALLY DRIVER' recommendations for DR):Overall Strength: 57%Spring Effect: 0Damper: 0Enable Spring 0% (not checked)Degrees of ROtation: 655Use Special Game Settings (UNCHECKED - unusual, but works for me)In Game Settings;Accel Sens: 20Accell Dead: 0Brake Sens:20Brake Dead: 0Steering Sens: 30Steering Dead: 0Force Feedback: 5%  (yes light as a feather guys it's what you need for decent Rally Driving!)Levle of Vibration: 65%Max Wheel Angle: 900  (yes this doesn't match the profiler , but it works, and grades the FFB right for me).Well each to his own, I think if you prefer HEAVIER wheel settings WRC 6 probably cannot be made to feel good because the weight is achieved in a terribly crude way in their FFB, not sure why it is so poor.  But  for LIGHT settings it;s not so much an issue.

												I was not expecting much but for twenty bucks I had to try the only other rally franchise that interested me over the years and am pleased to report that the game is actually good. Sure it doesnt feel as responsive or have as much physics into the driving model as our resident hero: Dirt...BUT it does very well for itself and after a few races I was able to get into that "rally flow" (flick left, right...feathering the brake...etc) and THAT is what matters ! I played a demo of this on console a few months back and hated it as it ran poorly but on PC this game handles pretty good with a higher fps and possibly better simulation model.As long as you're not trying to replace Dirt, this racer is a great addition to rally fans libraries.*UPDATE*  This game has some serious controller issues that need to be ironed out BUT with that being said, I have started playing the game using my Logitech Wheel and it's night and day in comparison...It's almost like theres a completely different driving model in-play when using a wheel and I would recommend using this control scheme as opposed to a controller.
